item.title: Ticket #1329 (Support for summer time / DST) updated
item.dc:creator: orangenormal
item.description:
rboren,

I'm sensitive to the complications of internationalization, but, honestly, I believe if there's a WordPress user in a country whose government changes weekly, they have other things to worry about than their Blog's DST settings.

My point is this: supporting *every* possible DST zone is unnecessary; just support the most popular ones (there are only going to be 4 or 5 that will cover more than 95% of the userbase). Time zones aren't necessary; Wordpress only needs to track the start/stop conditions for DST. (i.e. the first Sunday in April to the first Sunday in October, or whatever it happens to be -- I can never remember). For the remaining percentage of users whose DST zone is unsupported by those 4 or 5 defaults, you can use the "unfriendly" option of having them enter their own DST start and stop conditions or disable the automatic switching altogether -- heck, that can even be the default option.

Even if you don't include popular default DST zones, I suspect there are *plenty* of WP users who would be perfectly willing to settle for the "unfriendly" interface.

item.description: Are you sending multiple pings to the same site? If so, you will hit the comment flood check inside wp_new_comment(). The first ping will come through fine. item.title: Ticket #1329 (Support for summer time / DST) updated
item.dc:creator: ryan
item.description:
Read my comments in this thread:

​http://wordpress.org/support/topic/29648

"Automatic DST changing will likely never be in the WP core because getting it to work reliably across different servers and locales is a colossal chore. You simply can't rely on servers having a reliable and comprehensive TZ database, assuming they have one at all. Bundling a TZ database with WP is not an option because full TZ databases are many times the size of WP. Further, they require constant updating because DST rules are subject to the whims of government."

This is not trivial. If you think it is, try to implement it in a way that works for all locales and all platforms. The one way that will work consistently is to have the user define their transitions to and from DST -- in essence defining their own zone description ( Ex: ​http://www.w3.org/2002/12/cal/tzd/America/Chicago ). That's rather unfriendly though.

The clocks in your house adjust for DST? That's not typical. Those that accomplish this are usually sold into a specific market and have a targeted TZ database and a targeted operating environment. Or, they slave off of the NIST radio signal or the equivalent. WP does not have any of these luxuries.
